awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Spectrum Sharing Systems for Wireless Networks: Performance and privacy challenges
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid increase in the quantity and capability of consumer mobile wireless devices has accelerated the growth in demand for radio frequency spectrum. In recent years, to address congestion in allocated spectrum bands and allow for continued growth opportunities, national and international regulators have taken steps to identify new spectrum for use by mobile wireless services such as cellular and Wi-Fi. Unfortunately, myriad other systems and services already make use of spectrum in the frequency ranges that could be useful for mobile wireless. With limited opportunities to open up new unencumbered bands for spectrum hungry mobile wireless services, regulators are turning to spectrum sharing among increasingly broad system types as their only recourse. In two recent examples, the US Federal Communications Commission auctioned for cellular services two bands used by meteorological satellite services and US Navy radars, raising concerns about the interference to the incumbent services as well as the ability of incumbent services to maintain the privacy of their operations. 

This project explores a general framework for architecting spectrum sharing systems and examining design trades rigorously. The design goals of a spectrum sharing system will fall into three categories, namely, performance, privacy and complexity. The project will conduct formal optimization analysis to study the allocation of resources (time, frequency and power) among the various networks in terms of the resulting utility of the spectrum for those networks to maximize performance subject to interference constraints. Since the operational information about wireless systems needed to effect spectrum sharing, such as locations, frequencies, time of use, and susceptibility to interference, may be considered sensitive, this project will answer whether, under what conditions, and how a spectrum sharing system can be designed to protect a critical level of privacy for the systems it enables. To do so, the project will consider the scope of operational scenarios, adversary exploitation techniques, and obfuscation strategies to protect privacy, developing relevant metrics for the analysis.

por.por_cntn:
The demand for wireless broadband access keeps on increasing as citizens rely more and more on wireless end-user devices for work, entertainment and to socialize. Spectrum sharing promises to significantly improve wireless broadband access by sharing bandwidth originally assigned to governmental agencies with wireless broadband access providers. In this proposal we have designed and implemented the key algorithms for spectrum sharing systems. We have established via analysis, simulations, and experiments that these algorithms offer high performance gains while maintaining the privacy and security of the governmental agencies that share spectrum with commercial broadband access providers. 

The first key challenge is to assign transmission opportunities to broadband access devices like cell phones, without hurting via interference the operation of governmental agencies communications like weather satellites or military radars. We have introduced efficient algorithms to do so which are easy to implement, have low overhead, and achieve very close to optimal performance in practical scenarios.

The second key challenge is to operate the spectrum sharing system in a manner that protects the privacy of the incumbent governmental network, against adversaries that may use the spectrum sharing system to infer sensitive information. For example, consider an adversary that either hacks into the spectrum sharing system or operates its own end user devices in order to infer the location or operational parameters of military radars. Depending on the threat model, to achieve adequate protection of privacy the incumbent agency needs to obfuscate its information. Obfuscation comes at a performance cost. We have introduced efficient algorithms of low complexity which trade privacy and performance. We have shown via analysis and simulations that such algorithms can maximize privacy and achieve sizable performance gains in the context of both static and mobile incumbent networks.

We have also considered the presence of a passive sensor network whose goal is to passively monitor the incumbent network to allow sharing the spectrum efficiently, without the need for the incumbent network to share operational information with the spectrum sharing system. We have shown via analysis and simulations that this approach offers a less desirable tradeoff between privacy and performance, namely for the same performance gains it achieves less privacy than the obfuscation approach. This is primarily because an adversary that hacks into the sensing network may infer a lot of information about the incumbent network.

In summary, this proposal has designed and implemented key aspects of a spectrum sharing system such that the later can significantly improve the availability and speed of wireless broadband access while guaranteeing the privacy and security of the incumbent governmental agencies that share spectrum with commercial broadband access providers.
